elements.content: A versatile microporous metal–organic framework (MOF), {[Cu­(TIA)]·1.5CH3OH} n (Cu-1), was successfully obtained via the solvothermal reaction of cuprous­(II) salt with the bifunctional ligand 3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalic acid. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies indicate that Cu-1 contains an apo three-dimensional skeleton and two types of one-dimensional channels. The framework of Cu-1 has excellent acid-alkali resistance and thermal stability, which is stable in a pH = 2–13 aqueous solution and an 260 °C air environment. In addition, the microporous copper MOF shows very high uptakes of CO2 (180 cm3·g–1) and C2H2 (113 cm3·g–1) at 273 K and displays excellent adsorption selectivity for small molecular gases. The ideal adsorbed solution theory selectivity values for C2H2/C2H4, CO2/CH4, and CO2/N2 are 2, 9, and 22 at 298 K, respectively. At the same time, breakthrough experiments for CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 were further conducted to verify the efficient separation performances.

elements.content: Using a multifunctional ligand, 3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2TIA), a novel three-dimensional copper metal−organic framework, {[Cu­(TIA)]·1.5CH3OH} n (Cu-1), with polar micropores has been successfully obtained, and the framework of Cu-1 has excellent acid-alkali resistance and thermal stability. In addition, Cu-1 exhibits excellent uptakes of CO2 and C2H2. What is more, it displays excellent CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, which was also confirmed by breakthrough experiments.

elements.content: Following the rapid development of industry, the greenhouse effect caused by carbon dioxide (CO2) emission has become more and more serious. It has been estimated that more than half of the world’s CO2 emissions is exhausted from power plants. If the postconsumption CO2 can be directly captured from the flue gases before emission, the greenhouse effect will certainly be suppressed. Therefore, it is of utmost important to capture, store, and transform CO2 economically and efficiently. In addition, natural gas, as an important fossil fuel, is mainly composed of methane (CH4), which is considered to be the most promising alternative energy owing to its high energy conversion efficiency and low environmental impact. However, the CO2 existence in CH4 is a big problem, which not only sharply decreases the combustion calorific value but also causes terrible corrosion of the transmission pipeline, even in a small or trace concentration. Therefore, the removal of CO2 from natural gas is particularly important for its industrial application value. The latest developments of separation techniques and methods indicate that the selective capture of CO2 by porous materials is an environmentally friendly and low-energy-consumption method. In comparison with inorganic porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising materials for CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Following the rapid development of industry, the greenhouse effect caused by carbon dioxide (CO2) emission has become more and more serious. It has been estimated that more than half of the world's CO2 emissions is exhausted from power plants. If the postconsumption CO2 can be directly captured from the flue gases before emission, the greenhouse effect will certainly be suppressed. Therefore, it is of utmost important to capture, store, and transform CO2 economically and efficiently. In addition, natural gas, as an important fossil fuel, is mainly composed of methane (CH4), which is considered to be the most promising alternative energy owing to its high energy conversion efficiency and low environmental impact. However, the CO2 existence in CH4 is a big problem, which not only sharply decreases the combustion calorific value but also causes terrible corrosion of the transmission pipeline, even in a small or trace concentration. Therefore, the removal of CO2 from natural gas is particularly important for its industrial application value. The latest developments of separation techniques and methods indicate that the selective capture of CO2 by porous materials is an environmentally friendly and low-energy-consumption method. In comparison with inorganic porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered to be promising materials for CO2 adsorption.

elements.content: On the other hand, ethylene, as one of the most important feedstocks, has been widely used in the synthesis of industrial products such as fibers, rubber, plastics, and so on. In industry, ethylene is usually prepared by cracking petroleum and oxidative coupling of CH4 in natural gas; accordingly, a trace amount of acetylene (ca. 1%) as an impurity is mixed with ethylene. A trace amount of acetylene in ethylene can make the catalyst poisonous in the ethylene polymerization process by forming metal acetylides; therefore, it is critically important to deeply purify ethylene and thoroughly remove acetylene. However, unsaturated C2 hydrocarbons have similar physical and chemical properties and make separation even more difficult. In industry, cryogenic distillation at high pressure is usually used to separate light hydrocarbons, or solvent extraction and catalytic hydrogenation are used. These two methods either need high energy consumption or are accompanied by environmental pollution. Therefore, it is urgent to find a separation method with high efficiency and low energy consumption.

A trace amount of acetylene in ethylene can make the catalyst poisonous in the ethylene polymerization process by forming metal acetylides; therefore, it is critically important to deeply purify ethylene and thoroughly remove acetylene. However, unsaturated C2 hydrocarbons have similar physical and chemical properties and make separation even more difficult. In industry, cryogenic distillation at high pressure is usually used to separate light hydrocarbons, or solvent extraction and catalytic hydrogenation are used. These two methods either need high energy consumption or are accompanied by environmental pollution. Therefore, it is urgent to find a separation method with high efficiency and low energy consumption.

elements.content: MOFs, also known as porous coordination polymers, have been paid much attention because of their outstanding capabilities in the areas of gas deposition and segregation, luminescence, interfacial catalysis, and biomedicine. Compared with traditional porous materials such as activated carbon, molecular sieve, etc., the frame structure, pore shape and size, and functionalities of the MOFs could be regulated at the molecular level. These excellent properties have stimulated considerable research work on exploring their functions in gas selective adsorption and separation. In the recent 2 decades, MOFs have exhibited potential applications in CO2 capture, light hydrocarbon separation, and so on. Because of the special relationship between the structure and functionalization of MOF materials, MOFs can be designed and tuned by the suitable adjustment and selection of bridging linkers and metal units to meet the functional requirements. However, it is still a challenge to develop the MOF materials, which not only are able to capture CO2 from the fuel gases and but also can adsorb a trace amount of acetylene in ethylene. Because in practical application, the adsorption materials are required to have excellent adsorption performance and selectivity and at the same time can tolerate water and acid gas, which are always mixed in fuel and natural gases. Chemists found that high-valence conjugated carboxylic acid ligands can be used to synthesize water-stable MOFs. In addition, metal clusters, such as M2(COO)2 (M = Cu2+, Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+), as secondary building units (SBUs) can always be formed when organic ligands containing carboxyl groups are used. MOFs containing metal clusters as SBUs are always accompanied by permanent porosity and excellent sorption performance. What is more, on the basis of the theory of hard–soft acid–base, the MOFs formed by a combination of the soft base containing an azolate ring (such as pyrazolates, imidazolates, triazolates, and tetrazolates) and the bivalent transition soft acid metal ions (such as Cu2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, and Ni2+) are more stable. Bearing this in mind, a multifunctional ligand, 3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2TIA), was selected in our study. As expected, a porous MOF, namely, {[Cu­(TIA)]·1.5CH3OH} n (Cu-1), which contains the SBU of Cu2(COO)2, was successfully obtained. Cu-1 not only has exceptional thermal and chemical stability but also has two different sizes of micropores. Further study found that Cu-1 showed extraordinary adsorption capacities for CO2 (180 cm3·g–1 at 273 K) and C2H2 (113 cm3·g–1) as well as good CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 gas selectivity.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Commercial reactants and solvents were directly used without any further pretreatment, except that the solvent dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) needs to be tried by 4 Å molecular sieve and distilled under vacuum conditions. 3-(1H-1,2,4-Triazol-1-yl)isophthalic acid (H2TIA) was synthesized based on the method provided in the literature.

elements.content: H2TIA (11.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4′-PBY (7.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 5 mL of methanol were added in a 15 mL reactor in turn, and then the mixture was heated at 120 °C for 4 days. After that, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C·h–1. Blue rectangular crystals of Cu-1 (10.16 mg) were obtained (yield 65% based on H2TIA). Elem anal. Preparation of {[Cu(TIA)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (Cu-1)

H2TIA (11.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4'-PBY (7.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 5 mL of methanol were added in a 15 mL reactor in turn, and then the mixture was heated at 120 °C for 4 days. After that, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C⋅h-1. Blue rectangular crystals of Cu-1 (10.16 mg) were obtained (yield 65% based on H2TIA). Elem anal. elements.content: The synthesized sample of Cu-1 was activated at 70 °C for 10 h in vacuum conditions. N2 sorption isotherms were obtained from 0 to 1 bar at 77 K with liquid nitrogen by a volumetric method on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020HD88 surface area and pore analyzer. The low-pressure gas sorption data of CH4, CO2, and N2 were carried out on the same instruments, whereas the adsorption isotherms of light hydrocarbons such as C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of Cu-1 and Gas Sorption Measurements

The synthesized sample of Cu-1 was activated at 70 °C for 10 h in vacuum conditions. N2 sorption isotherms were obtained from 0 to 1 bar at 77 K with liquid nitrogen by a volumetric method on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020HD88 surface area and pore analyzer. The low-pressure gas sorption data of CH4, CO2, and N2 were carried out on the same instruments, whereas the adsorption isotherms of light hydrocarbons such as C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that Cu-1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group (Table S1), and the free methanol content of Cu-1 was further determined by the recognized means of SQUEEZE, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetry. In Cu-1, each asymmetric unit is composed of one Cu2+ ion, one TIA2– anion, and one and a half free methanol molecules. As displayed in a, the central Cu2+ ion existed in a pentacoordinated mode surrounded by four carboxylic O atoms and one triazole N atom from five different TIA2– ligands to form a square-pyramidal configuration. Four μ2-η1:η1-carboxyl bridges come from four distinct TIA2– ligands connected two Cu2+ ions to form a binuclear paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] moiety with a Cu–Cu separation of 2.668(1) Å (a). The CuII–O bond lengths vary from 1.960(3) to 2.027(4) Å, while the Cu–N bond distance is 2.129(4) Å (Table S2). In Cu-1, the dihedral angles formed between the triazolyl ring, the two carboxylate groups, and the central phenyl ring in the same TIA2– ligand are 19.160(2)°, 28.345(2)°, and 24.920(2)°, respectively. The paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] moieties are further connected by carboxylate groups and triazole N atoms from around the TIA2– anions to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework (b), with approximately rectangle dimensional channels with side lengths of about 6.9 × 5.7 Å exist along the c direction and irregular channels with an approximate size of 7.9 × 3.8 Å2 along the [110] direction (b,c). With the help of PLATON, the solvent-accessible void space of Cu-1 was calculated as 53.7%, which was occupied by free methanol molecules. From the perspective of topology, the TIA2– ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes, and the paddle wheel can be simplified as 6-connected nodes (d). Therefore, the structure of Cu-1 can be described as a new 3,6-connected apo framework.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Descriptions of Cu-1 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that Cu-1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group (Table S1), and the free methanol content of Cu-1 was further determined by the recognized means of SQUEEZE, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetry. In Cu-1, each asymmetric unit is composed of one Cu2+ ion, one TIA2- anion, and one and a half free methanol molecules. As displayed in a, the central Cu2+ ion existed in a pentacoordinated mode surrounded by four carboxylic O atoms and one triazole N atom from five different TIA2- ligands to form a square-pyramidal configuration. Four μ2-η1:η1-carboxyl bridges come from four distinct TIA2- ligands connected two Cu2+ ions to form a binuclear paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] moiety with a Cu-Cu separation of 2.668(1) Å (a). The CuII-O bond lengths vary from 1.960(3) to 2.027(4) Å, while the Cu-N bond distance is 2.129(4) Å (Table S2). In Cu-1, the dihedral angles formed between the triazolyl ring, the two carboxylate groups, and the central phenyl ring in the same TIA2- ligand are 19.160(2)°, 28.345(2)°, and 24.920(2)°, respectively. The paddle-wheel [Cu2(COO)4] moieties are further connected by carboxylate groups and triazole N atoms from around the TIA2- anions to form a three-dimensional (3D) framework (b), with approximately rectangle dimensional channels with side lengths of about 6.9 × 5.7 Å exist along the c direction and irregular channels with an approximate size of 7.9 × 3.8 Å2 along the [110] direction (b,c). With the help of PLATON, the solvent-accessible void space of Cu-1 was calculated as 53.7%, which was occupied by free methanol molecules. From the perspective of topology, the TIA2- ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes, and the paddle wheel can be simplified as 6-connected nodes (d). Therefore, the structure of Cu-1 can be described as a new 3,6-connected apo framework.

elements.content: It is worth noting that the channel wall of Cu-1 is modified by polar triazole rings that can be regarded as active sites, which can strengthen the interactions between the framework and the polar gases of small molecules such as CO2 and C2H2. Thus, the adsorption capacity and selectivity of these gases can be enhanced.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to confirm the stability of the MOF Cu-1. As can be seen from a, the framework of Cu-1 has outstanding acid–base stability, which can remain invariant in a wide range of pH = 2–13. In addition, the temperature-dependent PXRD pattern (b) and TGA curve (Figure S2) confirm that the framework also has excellent thermal stability, which can withstand high temperature up to 260 °C, and the structure of Cu-1 starts to collapse when the temperature is above 300 °C. Therefore, Cu-1 has excellent thermal and chemical stability, which is the basis for the following adsorption and separation experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Stabilities of Cu-1 

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to confirm the stability of the MOF Cu-1. As can be seen from a, the framework of Cu-1 has outstanding acid-base stability, which can remain invariant in a wide range of pH = 2-13. In addition, the temperature-dependent PXRD pattern (b) and TGA curve (Figure S2) confirm that the framework also has excellent thermal stability, which can withstand high temperature up to 260 °C, and the structure of Cu-1 starts to collapse when the temperature is above 300 °C. Therefore, Cu-1 has excellent thermal and chemical stability, which is the basis for the following adsorption and separation experiments.

elements.clean_text: 2  Stability of Cu-1: (a) PXRD patterns of the MOF Cu-1 after being soaked in different pH aqueous solutions for 48 h; (b) PXRD curves of the MOF Cu-1 after being heated at different temperatures for 2 h.

elements.content: N2 sorption–desorption isotherms of the activated Cu-1 were obtained to verify the permanent porosity. The results are exhibited in , a typical reversible type I isotherm behavior with a breakthrough uptake at P/P 0 < 0.01, explaining the characteristics of the micropores. At 77 K, the maximum uptake of N2 reached 270 cm3·g–1, and the corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were calculated as 766 and 1117 m2·g–1, respectively. In addition, it can be seen in b that there exist two kinds of pore systems. The large BET surface areas and various pore sizes inspire us to study the Cu-1 adsorption performance for small-molecule gases, such as CO2, N2, CH4, and C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6).
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

N2 sorption-desorption isotherms of the activated Cu-1 were obtained to verify the permanent porosity. The results are exhibited in , a typical reversible type I isotherm behavior with a breakthrough uptake at P/P 0 < 0.01, explaining the characteristics of the micropores. At 77 K, the maximum uptake of N2 reached 270 cm3⋅g-1, and the corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were calculated as 766 and 1117 m2⋅g-1, respectively. In addition, it can be seen in b that there exist two kinds of pore systems. The large BET surface areas and various pore sizes inspire us to study the Cu-1 adsorption performance for small-molecule gases, such as CO2, N2, CH4, and C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6).

elements.content: The single-component sorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, and N2 for Cu-1 at 273 and 298 K up to 1 bar () were collected to explore the abilities for adsorption and separation for these gases. As presented in a, Cu-1 has a very excellent CO2 uptake capacity of 128.77 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 1 bar, which is higher than the reported recorded value of bio-MOF-11 (92 cm3·g–1). In addition, the CO2 loading at 273 K and 1 bar of Cu-1 is 180.05 cm3·g–1; it also set a very excellernt value for CO2 adsorption compared with the reported highest uptake of NOTT-101 (164 cm3·g–1). The excellent adsorption properties of Cu-1 for CO2 can be ascribed to its higher surface area, multiple pores, the matching effect of micropoles, the size of the CO2 molecule, and the introduction of 1H-triazole rings in H2TIA, which can strengthen the affinity between the framework and CO2. Furthermore, Cu-1 exhibits a low adsorption capacity for CH4 (41.37 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 26.07 cm3·g–1 at 298 K) and N2 (11.46 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 9.81 cm3·g–1 at 298 K) under the condition of 1 bar. For the sake of detecting the interaction between gases and the framework of the MOF Cu-1, the isoteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2, N2, and CH4 was obtained based on the adsorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K with the help of a virial equation. As exhibited in , the Q st value of CO2 near zero loading is 27.6 kJ·mol–1; it slowly rises to 32 kJ·mol–1 following and increase of the adsorption capacity. For CH4 and N2, the zero-loading Q st values are 16.4 and 16.3 kJ·mol–1, respectively ().

elements.content: It is well-known that the selective adsorption and separation of light hydrocarbons play a vital role in the development of petrochemical enterprises. Considering the microporous characteristics of the MOF Cu-1, single components of C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6) were also carried out at 273 and 298 K with pressures from 0 to 1 bar. As shown in b, Cu-1 also displays high adsorption capacities for C2 hydrocarbons, and the corresponding uptakes are 112.88 cm3·g–1 and 5.04 mmol·g–1 for C2H2, 84.95 cm3·g–1 and 3.79 mmol·g–1 for C2H4, and 79.11 cm3·g–1 and 3.53 mmol·g–1 for C2H6 at 273 K. The adsorption capacity of Cu-1 at 298 K is basically similar to that of 273 K, which are 95.68 cm3·g–1 and 4.27 mmol·g–1 for C2H2, 68.06 cm3·g–1 and 3.04 mmol·g–1 for C2H4, and 57.99 cm3·g–1 and 2.59 mmol·g–1 for C2H6 at 298 K, respectively. The uptake for C2H2 at 298 K is higher than those of the famous MOFs UTSA-300 (76.4 cm3·g–1, 3.41 mmol·g–1), SIFSIX-3-Zn10 (86.5 cm3·g–1, 3.86 mmol·g–1), and NTU-65 (75.4 cm3·g–1, 3.36 mmol·g–1). Similarly, the interactions between the gases and MOF materials are also measured by calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) at 273 and 298 K; the values of Q st at low coverage are 30 kJ·mol–1 (C2H2), 27.3 kJ·mol–1 (C2H4), and 26.3 kJ·mol–1 (C2H6) ().

elements.content: In order to theoretically explore the excellent adsorption properties of the complexes for CO2 and acetylene, the distribution of CO2 and C2H2 molecules in Cu-1 at 300 K were confirmed by ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations. As exhibited in , the reason is that C2H2 and CO2 can have such a strong force with the framework by C–H···O and C–H···N interactions between guests and hosts. The O atoms in the CO2 molecule interact with the microporous channel walls through the strong interaction of C10–H10···O [H···O, 2.52 Å < 2.72 Å, the sum of van der Waals radii of the O (1.52 Å) and H (1.20 Å) atoms] and the weak interaction of C5–H5···O (H···O, 2.82 Å). Similarly, H atoms in acetylene form strong interactions with O and N atoms in the micropores through CH···O (2.61 Å) and CH···N (2.55 Å). Further, the simulated values of Q st for CO2 and C2H2 are 22.21 and 23.53 kJ·mol–1, respectively. On the basis of the above calculation results, it is precisely because the O atoms on polar CO of CO2 and acidic H atom in acetylene can form stronger interactions with the channel walls, resulting in better adsorption capacities for CO2 and C2H2.

elements.content: Inspired by the extremely high adsorption capacity of Cu-1 for CO2 compared with CH4 or N2, as well as the excellent uptake of C2H2 toward C2H4, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used to obtain the selectivity value. Complex Cu-1 displays a fairly high selectivity value of 22 at 298 K and 1 bar conditions with CO2/N2 mixed in a 15:85 molar ratio, which is higher than those of some reported MOFs. In addition, a selectivity product of 9 for CO2/CH4 at 298 K with the same mole ratio mixtures is achieved (a); the selectivity value for CO2/CH4 (50:50) is higher than some recently reported MOFs at the same condition. For binary mixtures of C2H2/C2H4, the adsorption selectivity in ratios of 50:50 (v/v) and 1:99 (v/v) at 298 K were 2.18 and 2.09, respectively (b), which is better than the famous NOTT-300 and MOF-74 systems.

elements.content: In order to detect the feasibility of the MOF Cu-1 in the actual gas purification process, dynamic breakthrough experiments were conducted by different ratios of CO2/N2 (10:90), CO2/CH4 (50:50), and C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixed gases passing through a packed column containing 744 mg of solid Cu-1 with a flow rate of 2 mL·min–1 at 298 K. The results exhibit that not only can CO2 be effectively separated from the mixed gases of CO2/N2 (10:90) and CO2/CH4 (50:50) but also acetylene can be effectively separated from a C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture (a–c). For the CO2/N2 (10:90) mixture, it only takes 253 s for nitrogen to pass through the fixed bed, whereas the elution of CO2 gas needs 33 min. For a CO2/CH4 (50:50) mixed gas, CH4 gas needs 600 s to break through the fixed bed, but CO2 gas takes an additional 39 min. The breakthrough experiments further verified the feasibility that the MOF Cu-1 can serve as an adsorbent in the purification of natural gas and selectively capturing CO2 from fuel gas in industry. In addition, the same test of the MOF Cu-1 to C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture shows that pure ethylene was first detected from the outflow gas, and acetylene was not detected at this period of time. After 20 min, the acetylene adsorption capacity reached saturation and broke through the adsorbent (c). The results confirm that the MOF Cu-1 can also be used in the deep purification of ethylene in industrial production.
elements.clean_text:
Breakthrough Experiments

In order to detect the feasibility of the MOF Cu-1 in the actual gas purification process, dynamic breakthrough experiments were conducted by different ratios of CO2/N2 (10:90), CO2/CH4 (50:50), and C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixed gases passing through a packed column containing 744 mg of solid Cu-1 with a flow rate of 2 mL⋅min-1 at 298 K. The results exhibit that not only can CO2 be effectively separated from the mixed gases of CO2/N2 (10:90) and CO2/CH4 (50:50) but also acetylene can be effectively separated from a C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture (a-c). For the CO2/N2 (10:90) mixture, it only takes 253 s for nitrogen to pass through the fixed bed, whereas the elution of CO2 gas needs 33 min. For a CO2/CH4 (50:50) mixed gas, CH4 gas needs 600 s to break through the fixed bed, but CO2 gas takes an additional 39 min. The breakthrough experiments further verified the feasibility that the MOF Cu-1 can serve as an adsorbent in the purification of natural gas and selectively capturing CO2 from fuel gas in industry. In addition, the same test of the MOF Cu-1 to C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture shows that pure ethylene was first detected from the outflow gas, and acetylene was not detected at this period of time. After 20 min, the acetylene adsorption capacity reached saturation and broke through the adsorbent (c). The results confirm that the MOF Cu-1 can also be used in the deep purification of ethylene in industrial production.

elements.content: In summary, a versatile microporous MOF Cu-1 was successfully obtained based on the bifunctional ligand H2TIA, which not only has excellent acid-alkali resistance and thermal stability but also possesses polar micropores, which can match CO2 and C2H2 molecules very well. The microporous MOF shows very high uptakes of CO2 and C2H2. In addition, it displays good CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, which was also confirmed by breakthrough experiments. The high adsorption capacity for CO2 and high selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 make it a possible ideal substitute for capturing postconsumption CO2 and purifying of natural gas. What is more, the excellent uptake for C2H2 and the corresponding breakthrough experiment suggest its application prospect in the deep purification of ethylene in petrochemical enterprises.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a versatile microporous MOF Cu-1 was successfully obtained based on the bifunctional ligand H2TIA, which not only has excellent acid-alkali resistance and thermal stability but also possesses polar micropores, which can match CO2 and C2H2 molecules very well. The microporous MOF shows very high uptakes of CO2 and C2H2. In addition, it displays good CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 selectivity, which was also confirmed by breakthrough experiments. The high adsorption capacity for CO2 and high selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 make it a possible ideal substitute for capturing postconsumption CO2 and purifying of natural gas. What is more, the excellent uptake for C2H2 and the corresponding breakthrough experiment suggest its application prospect in the deep purification of ethylene in petrochemical enterprises.

Preparation of {[Cu(TIA)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (Cu-1)

H2TIA (11.7 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4'-PBY (7.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), and 5 mL of methanol were added in a 15 mL reactor in turn, and then the mixture was heated at 120 °C for 4 days. After that, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C⋅h-1. Blue rectangular crystals of Cu-1 (10.16 mg) were obtained (yield 65% based on H2TIA). Elem anal. cln_elements.content:
A versatile microporous metal–organic framework (MOF), {[Cu­(TIA)]·1.5CH3OH} n (Cu-1), was successfully obtained via the solvothermal reaction of cuprous­(II) salt with the bifunctional ligand 3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalic acid. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies indicate that Cu-1 contains an apo three-dimensional skeleton and two types of one-dimensional channels. The framework of Cu-1 has excellent acid-alkali resistance and thermal stability, which is stable in a pH = 2–13 aqueous solution and an 260 °C air environment. In addition, the microporous copper MOF shows very high uptakes of CO2 (180 cm3·g–1) and C2H2 (113 cm3·g–1) at 273 K and displays excellent adsorption selectivity for small molecular gases. The ideal adsorbed solution theory selectivity values for C2H2/C2H4, CO2/CH4, and CO2/N2 are 2, 9, and 22 at 298 K, respectively. At the same time, breakthrough experiments for CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 were further conducted to verify the efficient separation performances.

MOFs, also known as porous coordination polymers, have been paid much attention because of their outstanding capabilities in the areas of gas deposition and segregation, luminescence, interfacial catalysis, and biomedicine. Compared with traditional porous materials such as activated carbon, molecular sieve, etc., the frame structure, pore shape and size, and functionalities of the MOFs could be regulated at the molecular level. These excellent properties have stimulated considerable research work on exploring their functions in gas selective adsorption and separation. In the recent 2 decades, MOFs have exhibited potential applications in CO2 capture, light hydrocarbon separation, and so on. Because of the special relationship between the structure and functionalization of MOF materials, MOFs can be designed and tuned by the suitable adjustment and selection of bridging linkers and metal units to meet the functional requirements. However, it is still a challenge to develop the MOF materials, which not only are able to capture CO2 from the fuel gases and but also can adsorb a trace amount of acetylene in ethylene. Because in practical application, the adsorption materials are required to have excellent adsorption performance and selectivity and at the same time can tolerate water and acid gas, which are always mixed in fuel and natural gases. Chemists found that high-valence conjugated carboxylic acid ligands can be used to synthesize water-stable MOFs. In addition, metal clusters, such as M2(COO)2 (M = Cu2+, Zn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+), as secondary building units (SBUs) can always be formed when organic ligands containing carboxyl groups are used. MOFs containing metal clusters as SBUs are always accompanied by permanent porosity and excellent sorption performance. What is more, on the basis of the theory of hard–soft acid–base, the MOFs formed by a combination of the soft base containing an azolate ring (such as pyrazolates, imidazolates, triazolates, and tetrazolates) and the bivalent transition soft acid metal ions (such as Cu2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, and Ni2+) are more stable. Bearing this in mind, a multifunctional ligand, 3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2TIA), was selected in our study. As expected, a porous MOF, namely, {[Cu­(TIA)]·1.5CH3OH} n (Cu-1), which contains the SBU of Cu2(COO)2, was successfully obtained. Cu-1 not only has exceptional thermal and chemical stability but also has two different sizes of micropores. Further study found that Cu-1 showed extraordinary adsorption capacities for CO2 (180 cm3·g–1 at 273 K) and C2H2 (113 cm3·g–1) as well as good CO2/CH4, CO2/N2, and C2H2/C2H4 gas selectivity.

Stabilities of <bold>Cu-1</bold>

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to confirm the stability of the MOF Cu-1. As can be seen from a, the framework of Cu-1 has outstanding acid–base stability, which can remain invariant in a wide range of pH = 2–13. In addition, the temperature-dependent PXRD pattern (b) and TGA curve (Figure S2) confirm that the framework also has excellent thermal stability, which can withstand high temperature up to 260 °C, and the structure of Cu-1 starts to collapse when the temperature is above 300 °C. Therefore, Cu-1 has excellent thermal and chemical stability, which is the basis for the following adsorption and separation experiments.

Gas Sorption Properties

N2 sorption–desorption isotherms of the activated Cu-1 were obtained to verify the permanent porosity. The results are exhibited in , a typical reversible type I isotherm behavior with a breakthrough uptake at P/P 0 < 0.01, explaining the characteristics of the micropores. At 77 K, the maximum uptake of N2 reached 270 cm3·g–1, and the corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were calculated as 766 and 1117 m2·g–1, respectively. In addition, it can be seen in b that there exist two kinds of pore systems. The large BET surface areas and various pore sizes inspire us to study the Cu-1 adsorption performance for small-molecule gases, such as CO2, N2, CH4, and C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6).

The single-component sorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, and N2 for Cu-1 at 273 and 298 K up to 1 bar () were collected to explore the abilities for adsorption and separation for these gases. As presented in a, Cu-1 has a very excellent CO2 uptake capacity of 128.77 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 1 bar, which is higher than the reported recorded value of bio-MOF-11 (92 cm3·g–1). In addition, the CO2 loading at 273 K and 1 bar of Cu-1 is 180.05 cm3·g–1; it also set a very excellernt value for CO2 adsorption compared with the reported highest uptake of NOTT-101 (164 cm3·g–1). The excellent adsorption properties of Cu-1 for CO2 can be ascribed to its higher surface area, multiple pores, the matching effect of micropoles, the size of the CO2 molecule, and the introduction of 1H-triazole rings in H2TIA, which can strengthen the affinity between the framework and CO2. Furthermore, Cu-1 exhibits a low adsorption capacity for CH4 (41.37 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 26.07 cm3·g–1 at 298 K) and N2 (11.46 cm3·g–1 at 273 K and 9.81 cm3·g–1 at 298 K) under the condition of 1 bar. For the sake of detecting the interaction between gases and the framework of the MOF Cu-1, the isoteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2, N2, and CH4 was obtained based on the adsorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K with the help of a virial equation. As exhibited in , the Q st value of CO2 near zero loading is 27.6 kJ·mol–1; it slowly rises to 32 kJ·mol–1 following and increase of the adsorption capacity. For CH4 and N2, the zero-loading Q st values are 16.4 and 16.3 kJ·mol–1, respectively ().

It is well-known that the selective adsorption and separation of light hydrocarbons play a vital role in the development of petrochemical enterprises. Considering the microporous characteristics of the MOF Cu-1, single components of C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6) were also carried out at 273 and 298 K with pressures from 0 to 1 bar. As shown in b, Cu-1 also displays high adsorption capacities for C2 hydrocarbons, and the corresponding uptakes are 112.88 cm3·g–1 and 5.04 mmol·g–1 for C2H2, 84.95 cm3·g–1 and 3.79 mmol·g–1 for C2H4, and 79.11 cm3·g–1 and 3.53 mmol·g–1 for C2H6 at 273 K. The adsorption capacity of Cu-1 at 298 K is basically similar to that of 273 K, which are 95.68 cm3·g–1 and 4.27 mmol·g–1 for C2H2, 68.06 cm3·g–1 and 3.04 mmol·g–1 for C2H4, and 57.99 cm3·g–1 and 2.59 mmol·g–1 for C2H6 at 298 K, respectively. The uptake for C2H2 at 298 K is higher than those of the famous MOFs UTSA-300 (76.4 cm3·g–1, 3.41 mmol·g–1), SIFSIX-3-Zn10 (86.5 cm3·g–1, 3.86 mmol·g–1), and NTU-65 (75.4 cm3·g–1, 3.36 mmol·g–1). Similarly, the interactions between the gases and MOF materials are also measured by calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) at 273 and 298 K; the values of Q st at low coverage are 30 kJ·mol–1 (C2H2), 27.3 kJ·mol–1 (C2H4), and 26.3 kJ·mol–1 (C2H6) ().

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were conducted to confirm the stability of the MOF Cu-1. As can be seen from a, the framework of Cu-1 has outstanding acid-base stability, which can remain invariant in a wide range of pH = 2-13. In addition, the temperature-dependent PXRD pattern (b) and TGA curve (Figure S2) confirm that the framework also has excellent thermal stability, which can withstand high temperature up to 260 °C, and the structure of Cu-1 starts to collapse when the temperature is above 300 °C. Therefore, Cu-1 has excellent thermal and chemical stability, which is the basis for the following adsorption and separation experiments.

Gas Sorption Properties

N2 sorption-desorption isotherms of the activated Cu-1 were obtained to verify the permanent porosity. The results are exhibited in , a typical reversible type I isotherm behavior with a breakthrough uptake at P/P 0 < 0.01, explaining the characteristics of the micropores. At 77 K, the maximum uptake of N2 reached 270 cm3⋅g-1, and the corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas were calculated as 766 and 1117 m2⋅g-1, respectively. In addition, it can be seen in b that there exist two kinds of pore systems. The large BET surface areas and various pore sizes inspire us to study the Cu-1 adsorption performance for small-molecule gases, such as CO2, N2, CH4, and C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6).

The single-component sorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, and N2 for Cu-1 at 273 and 298 K up to 1 bar () were collected to explore the abilities for adsorption and separation for these gases. As presented in a, Cu-1 has a very excellent CO2 uptake capacity of 128.77 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K and 1 bar, which is higher than the reported recorded value of bio-MOF-11 (92 cm3⋅g-1). In addition, the CO2 loading at 273 K and 1 bar of Cu-1 is 180.05 cm3⋅g-1; it also set a very excellernt value for CO2 adsorption compared with the reported highest uptake of NOTT-101 (164 cm3⋅g-1). The excellent adsorption properties of Cu-1 for CO2 can be ascribed to its higher surface area, multiple pores, the matching effect of micropoles, the size of the CO2 molecule, and the introduction of 1H-triazole rings in H2TIA, which can strengthen the affinity between the framework and CO2. Furthermore, Cu-1 exhibits a low adsorption capacity for CH4 (41.37 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K and 26.07 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K) and N2 (11.46 cm3⋅g-1 at 273 K and 9.81 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K) under the condition of 1 bar. For the sake of detecting the interaction between gases and the framework of the MOF Cu-1, the isoteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of CO2, N2, and CH4 was obtained based on the adsorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K with the help of a virial equation. As exhibited in , the Q st value of CO2 near zero loading is 27.6 kJ⋅mol-1; it slowly rises to 32 kJ⋅mol-1 following and increase of the adsorption capacity. For CH4 and N2, the zero-loading Q st values are 16.4 and 16.3 kJ⋅mol-1, respectively ().

It is well-known that the selective adsorption and separation of light hydrocarbons play a vital role in the development of petrochemical enterprises. Considering the microporous characteristics of the MOF Cu-1, single components of C2 hydrocarbons (C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6) were also carried out at 273 and 298 K with pressures from 0 to 1 bar. As shown in b, Cu-1 also displays high adsorption capacities for C2 hydrocarbons, and the corresponding uptakes are 112.88 cm3⋅g-1 and 5.04 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H2, 84.95 cm3⋅g-1 and 3.79 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H4, and 79.11 cm3⋅g-1 and 3.53 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H6 at 273 K. The adsorption capacity of Cu-1 at 298 K is basically similar to that of 273 K, which are 95.68 cm3⋅g-1 and 4.27 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H2, 68.06 cm3⋅g-1 and 3.04 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H4, and 57.99 cm3⋅g-1 and 2.59 mmol⋅g-1 for C2H6 at 298 K, respectively. The uptake for C2H2 at 298 K is higher than those of the famous MOFs UTSA-300 (76.4 cm3⋅g-1, 3.41 mmol⋅g-1), SIFSIX-3-Zn10 (86.5 cm3⋅g-1, 3.86 mmol⋅g-1), and NTU-65 (75.4 cm3⋅g-1, 3.36 mmol⋅g-1). Similarly, the interactions between the gases and MOF materials are also measured by calculation of the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) at 273 and 298 K; the values of Q st at low coverage are 30 kJ⋅mol-1 (C2H2), 27.3 kJ⋅mol-1 (C2H4), and 26.3 kJ⋅mol-1 (C2H6) ().

In order to theoretically explore the excellent adsorption properties of the complexes for CO2 and acetylene, the distribution of CO2 and C2H2 molecules in Cu-1 at 300 K were confirmed by ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations. As exhibited in , the reason is that C2H2 and CO2 can have such a strong force with the framework by C–H···O and C–H···N interactions between guests and hosts. The O atoms in the CO2 molecule interact with the microporous channel walls through the strong interaction of C10–H10···O [H···O, 2.52 Å < 2.72 Å, the sum of van der Waals radii of the O (1.52 Å) and H (1.20 Å) atoms] and the weak interaction of C5–H5···O (H···O, 2.82 Å). Similarly, H atoms in acetylene form strong interactions with O and N atoms in the micropores through CH···O (2.61 Å) and CH···N (2.55 Å). Further, the simulated values of Q st for CO2 and C2H2 are 22.21 and 23.53 kJ·mol–1, respectively. On the basis of the above calculation results, it is precisely because the O atoms on polar CO of CO2 and acidic H atom in acetylene can form stronger interactions with the channel walls, resulting in better adsorption capacities for CO2 and C2H2.

Inspired by the extremely high adsorption capacity of Cu-1 for CO2 compared with CH4 or N2, as well as the excellent uptake of C2H2 toward C2H4, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was used to obtain the selectivity value. Complex Cu-1 displays a fairly high selectivity value of 22 at 298 K and 1 bar conditions with CO2/N2 mixed in a 15:85 molar ratio, which is higher than those of some reported MOFs. In addition, a selectivity product of 9 for CO2/CH4 at 298 K with the same mole ratio mixtures is achieved (a); the selectivity value for CO2/CH4 (50:50) is higher than some recently reported MOFs at the same condition. For binary mixtures of C2H2/C2H4, the adsorption selectivity in ratios of 50:50 (v/v) and 1:99 (v/v) at 298 K were 2.18 and 2.09, respectively (b), which is better than the famous NOTT-300 and MOF-74 systems.

Breakthrough Experiments

In order to detect the feasibility of the MOF Cu-1 in the actual gas purification process, dynamic breakthrough experiments were conducted by different ratios of CO2/N2 (10:90), CO2/CH4 (50:50), and C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixed gases passing through a packed column containing 744 mg of solid Cu-1 with a flow rate of 2 mL·min–1 at 298 K. The results exhibit that not only can CO2 be effectively separated from the mixed gases of CO2/N2 (10:90) and CO2/CH4 (50:50) but also acetylene can be effectively separated from a C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture (a–c). For the CO2/N2 (10:90) mixture, it only takes 253 s for nitrogen to pass through the fixed bed, whereas the elution of CO2 gas needs 33 min. For a CO2/CH4 (50:50) mixed gas, CH4 gas needs 600 s to break through the fixed bed, but CO2 gas takes an additional 39 min. The breakthrough experiments further verified the feasibility that the MOF Cu-1 can serve as an adsorbent in the purification of natural gas and selectively capturing CO2 from fuel gas in industry. In addition, the same test of the MOF Cu-1 to C2H2/C2H4 (1:99) mixture shows that pure ethylene was first detected from the outflow gas, and acetylene was not detected at this period of time. After 20 min, the acetylene adsorption capacity reached saturation and broke through the adsorbent (c). The results confirm that the MOF Cu-1 can also be used in the deep purification of ethylene in industrial production.
